In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

In Julia, we can use the DataFrames package to work with data frames. Here is how you could solve this task:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars) 
    df = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    
    for i in eachrow(df) 
        @view(i.audi_a4_type) = true
    end
    
    return df
end
```
This function `audi_filter` first filters the dataframe to only include rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and either the model is "a4" or "a4 quattro". Then it goes through each row in this filtered data frame, setting a new column `audi_a4_type` to true. Finally, the resulting DataFrame with all of these modifications is returned.
